Check it out!
I'm working on an IPFS video integration which is streamlined to dynamically grab video information from Json files. I'm quite shocked how easy it is to do these things javascript only.

AHHHHH CORS is being a pain in the butt. I can't do any in browser requests to things on the same domain due to ZeroNet running on localhost without Access-Control-Allow-Origin: [domain]! I need to rethink this json request process....

Image related [NSFW]

Finished the style testing and regular video playback. It's very polished and pretty. Check it out: http://127.0.0.1:43110/16pz3DbSRyz7D7e3qsxWMq98Z8VztJZN4j

Next is trying to figure out this CORS stuff can be overcome so we can get some dynamic playback.

So I can't request Json objects or set cookies because of the zeronet sandbox. This makes my dynamic video information idea a lot hard to do than I thought it would be. 

Possible solutions are creating a zeronet database and then making a way to populate it or using a kind of hash pointer to identify what page you are on and completing the task in javascript. I'm going to try the later one.

AH HAHAHAHAHAAHHA! I GOT IT I FINALLY GOT THE DYNAMIC CONTENT RELOAD WORKING! It's soo beautiful! 

You can see the whole Astarotte no Omocha! series now! http://127.0.0.1:43110/16pz3DbSRyz7D7e3qsxWMq98Z8VztJZN4j/

Next is figuring out how to get full screen working....

## Running IPFS in the background on Linux

If you have a VPS or Dedicated Server and wish to help the IPFS network stay healthy you can continually run IPFS in the background. To do this just run the simple lines below in a fresh SSH connection.

> nohup ipfs daemon &

This should output a job ID (should look like [1] 1234 with the end numbers being different)

> disown %1

Depending what is inside the [number] you might need to change the %1 to %2 or %3, etc. 

There you go! You can now close your SSH connection. IPFS will remain running in the background spreading out any of your pins and helping the health of the IPFS network.

comment.body: @Peponi: https://i.imgur.com/z2DyGWj.gif
@Imahugefaggot: Already did. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
@TCP: Seems available to me. Do you have tor enabled?
@Arkre: I agree. But I don't see a reason why anons would only visit and contribute to a single site.
@Lmath: I've setup a VPS to host oniichan. Both clear and tor connections should be  able to connect. I can also package the site folder in an archive for those who still can't connect from China.
@Lmath I can cater.
@Gremious: But it doesn't yet have image upload. I wonder why they made a fork? They could have sent a pull request in to the main repo.
@Nekololi: <3
@Zeronet0: Everyone has their own tastes.

@Th3B3st: Oh my. That is quite the chunk of CPU Chrome is using. I wonder why is that... if the video is pinned or fully loaded the CPU goes down to regular rate. I think it's an issue with the way Chrome handles the buffering with mediaelement.
@Th3B3st: I've configured media element to be less aggressive. It seems to have fixed the CPU problem on my end somewhat. Still a little bit too high for my tastes.

@Th3B3st: I personally use Firefox and it works flawlessly. If anyone is having issues my recommendation is either to pin the file and wait for IPFS to download all the chunks or switch over to Firefox and stream it as intended.

@12hstudy: Is it just loading and can't seem to find a connection? Try pinning the video and resolving to a direct peer. If you have zeronet and ipfs running with an active connection to a direct peer (who has the file) you have all the prerequisites.
@12hstudy: You can try to use a ipfs gateway to get the file. https://gateway.ipfs.io/ipfs/QmdunRrWGLhuCYpDPXvKuCvCGSAZhr7Fw3ZwycxtEUGeeP
@12hstudy: Ahh. Sure. You're welcome... I guess.
@Lmath: The CROS request flowchart which is completely broken when using zeronet. I'm trying to find a way around it without any luck. Stupid sandboxing. lol

@12hstudy: Well I was going to use Polymer but CORS and zeronet sandboxing prevents html imports. So I had to grab a free html5 template and edited it to fit the site's purpose. Using document.write I can split up the html systems into separate files with a downside of needing so many escape characters to output a result. The main part I'm now working on is detecting hash changes and grabbing information depending on that hash in a kind of array type system.
@12hstudy: I didn't think of using bootstrap-treeview... A little too late now but thanks for the info. I'll keep it in mind next time.
@Glw:  "How to use AH?" Well you will need to run IPFS (and zeronet) on your system and then go to the video page. That's it. Everything else is taken care of. :)
@12hstudy: You need to make sure to do a full update. There should be a next video button below the episode summary. Press it and be amazed by all it's awesomeness.

@12hstudy: When I visited china, to get around a lot of the restrictions, I setup a SoftEther VPN server using a OVH VPS. Set the port to 443 and the connection type to TCP to pass the firewall without any issues. SoftEther tunnels the connection using traditional https protocols (unlike the default openvpn) which makes DPI blocking a thing of the past. It just looks like you are talking with a website. You can also try to do a SSH tunnel but I didn't have much luck with that.
@12hstudy: Ya not everyone would know. But that doesn't mean you couldn't do it.

@Awdhax: China's firewall blocks certain types of peer to peer connections. While it is true that as more people in China use IPFS and Zeronet it would get faster, China has a habit to block things that overcome their censorship. I'm not in China right now (so I can't test it) but it's quite noticeable when they start to do DPI on your connection. Throughput drops significantly and sometimes can make your connection so sluggish it's not worth the time.
I think you would be interested in [oniichan's #Teamfelix thread](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1BuPsjT1AC5vjoAd4PmJMt4TaZvh3cgKNX/?/b/thread/b4900fc941cfd0cc8d553e128444654b)
@Johnbyte1221: @Johnbyte1221: That's a zeronet wrapper error (from not having all the files or an updated zeronet client). You just need to refresh the page and it should load.

@12hstudy: I've tried a couple tests using fragmented mp4 files. It doesn't seem that there is any improvements when streaming via IPFS. It might have to do with how IPFS splits the file into data blocks.
@12hstudy: Good idea. I'm going to do that.
@12hstudy: If you have 2G or 3G connections I would recommend you pin the videos. Which is now completely do able with one click. :D

@12hstudy: MP4 videos are specifically made to allow streaming. IPFS is also designed to split the file in blocks to allow streaming even if the file is only partly done. There is really no way to make it easier for people who have slow internet to resolve and download the file faster. It's a problem on their end not mine. If people pin it in China it will be much faster for them. Just takes some time to first get in.
@莱文倩: No this is a girl's panty shot. Later on I will be looking at adding super lovers for those boy lovers out there.
@猫叉酱: That is the prettiest nullchan engine I've ever seen. In more ways than one. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

@Aycaramba: The basic idea is very simple:

1. Javascript array with all the file information (such as ipfs hash ids)
2. Template file with all relevant divs having a unique id with link to unique javascript array
3. Javascript file that parses the array and updates the template with the relevant information.
For step one I was going to do a pure JSON file for ease of use but CORS isn't allowed in the Zeronet sandbox. There is a couple ways around it though.
@Aycaramba: Cloning IPFS video is as simple as copying the website files over to your own site directory and replacing the content.json. Everything is editable and easy to figure out.
@12hlearn @Ddjj @Firedog: I feel like I'm missing something here.
@12hlearn: Ah that makes sense. Thanks for explaining.

@Aycaramba: The video hash was should be located inside the video series javascript since the Kodomo no Jikan upload. I would recommend you update IPFS Videos to get the latest code. IPFS as a limit on how much you can defaultly store. IPFS Videos now has over 10GB worth of video files. If you are getting a pinning error, your storage might be full; you will need to [change your storage max to a higher allocation](http://127.0.0.1:5001/ipfs/QmU3o9bvfenhTKhxUakbYrLDnZU7HezAVxPM6Ehjw9Xjqy/#/config).
@Zerocatty: No this is hentai. No children were used in the making of this image.
@Aycaramba: Glad to hear. If you have any issues you can always comment. If I don't respond it's best to [email me](/Mail.ZeroNetwork.bit/?to=loligod).

@Nekololi: While that is partly true it's only a part of the solution. If you logout of the console IPFS might get closed because linux will send a SIGHUP to the background running processes in your instance. Using nohup protects against that and also gives you a way to get any crash info (being that the process outputs will be appended to a file) if it does die.

@Nekololi: Disown should take care of the problems alone but from my tests (maybe it's because I'm using a weird terminal) it always seems to send an interrupt signal to IPFS, so to me it only solves part of the solution. The IPFS daemon doesn't allow any inputs (other than the interrupt) and being that it binds the ports with a pretty good API  I personally wish they had a background daemon option. For the past couple days I have had IPFS just quit when I was only using disown for it. nohup with disown seems to solve the issue.

@12hlearn: Infile subtitles doesn't work with html5 (to my knowledge). I could try to setup multi-track audio using a player like jwplayer or make a control interface myself.  It's pretty complicated to get right, especially with the zeronet sandbox and how IPFS video is setup. I'll give it a try. If it works people could steal the code for their own player.
@Arkre: I should really read the zeroframe reference.

@Aycaramba: I like how Zeronet handles the site integration and content updating. It also gives capability to add in databases and user authentication in a distributed manner. Using IPFS (via IPNS) for content updating is a pain the the butt compared to Zeronet. There is also a lot more users here than in the IPFS network.
That's a great photo!
Seriously amazing work. You really did rewrite it all.
@sthetz: Alt.Sex.Stories Text Repository http://www.asstr.org/main.html

@P2P: Very true. We need to make sure individuals can access it. You can help with the distribution by [clicking here](http://localhost:5001/api/v0/pin/add?arg=QmcniBv7UQ4gGPQQW2BwbD4ZZHzN3o3tPuNLZCbBchd1zh) to pin the video. It will be a great help.

@P2P: IPFS was designed with an OPT-IN file hosting policy. When you view a file on IPFS it gets stored in a temporary cache which later gets cleaned by a garbage collector. You can pin the file manually to keep it from being cleaned. In this sense it's designed closer to bittorrent than Zeronet or Freenet.
@Nofish We need a translation plug-in ASAP.
@Nofish: Translation plugin which would allow the translation of text within a zeronet website. Mainly to help with the translation of submitted user content.
@Zerochan: You got it.

@Zerochan: It would be interesting if zeronet could integrate IPFS like it did with Tor. The content addressing alone would be a major performance boost to the network. It would be the solution to the current large file block issue zeronet has.

@Zerochan: It would also be able to rely on IPFS's instantaneous object linking which would not only shard and authenticate the file data structure but optionally directory structures as well. It's also be possible to set up a versioned file system referencing newly updated zeronet sites.
@12hlearn: I'm more looking forward to [js-ipfs](https://github.com/ipfs/js-ipfs) being completed. Afterwards integration would be as simple as adding the javascript file to the zeronet site.

@Nofish Is there any ETA on large file support? Either using BitTorrent or otherwise to accomplish it. [ZeroMux](https://github.com/MuxZeroNet/ZeroMux) has some interesting features but ultimately it's just a hack which isn't the most effective or capable large file transfer method out there. If you have a solution in the works please let me know. I've been testing methods like mad.
@Linker: All the included content will be hardcore in nature. No softcore stuff will be included.
@Firebox: Do you have a link for the player's files?
There is no rush. I got the html5 player working inside the sandbox properly.
@12hlearn: Oh cool they finally added support for fullscreen. Seems simple enough to add in to the player.

If you are having troubles resolving the videos you can [resolve to a direct peer here](http://localhost:5001/api/v0/swarm/connect?arg=/ip4/149.56.14.160/tcp/4001/ipfs/QmU33iCTrgMhurhEvLG25j4AMz82r8P3wqBPwUAtKmBHXX).

[Pinning the collection](http://localhost:5001/api/v0/pin/add?arg=QmeXJeyHtg5DYnbruJCypje85DNLDdPy5iV3a3XDmndUAJ&arg=QmdWffCXaopF4j1k9d1DCzz6891zT9bcXmSowZsMTB81K6) not only helps keep the files alive but also speeds up the download.
@12hlearn: IPFS works really good for large file distribution. Maxing out connections in a matter of moments which unfortunately is not something I can see Zeronet doing anytime soon.

@Evanescence: If the videos are loading too slow for you, [resolve to a direct peer](http://localhost:5001/api/v0/swarm/connect?arg=/ip4/149.56.14.160/tcp/4001/ipfs/QmU33iCTrgMhurhEvLG25j4AMz82r8P3wqBPwUAtKmBHXX) and [pin the collection](http://localhost:5001/api/v0/pin/add?arg=QmeXJeyHtg5DYnbruJCypje85DNLDdPy5iV3a3XDmndUAJ&arg=QmdWffCXaopF4j1k9d1DCzz6891zT9bcXmSowZsMTB81K6).
@Zerochan: Oh now that is just going to crash the gateway. lol

@Firebox: Yep. But unfortunately I couldn't get the demo provided in the repo to work so I stole most of the code from the examples you had on the "in the wild page". I was shocked how easy it was to split the files up into the chunks using the included python script.

IPFS is better for file sharing, while Zeronet is better for displaying web content. If anything, it'd be better to marry the two rather than pitting them against each other, as they're mutually beneficial.

[credit](https://www.reddit.com/r/zeronet/comments/4vajt5/zeronet_vs_ipfs_whats_the_difference/)

Those 1 file errors are annoying. The most effective way I found to get rid of them is going to the content.json and removing all the file links with sha512 (resetting to "files": {},). Afterwards I resign and boom the error goes away. :D

@Rypedub: Loli (or Lolicon) is derived from the term 'lolita complex' from Nabokov's novel "Lolita." It's a blanket term for a prepubescent girl (primarily ages 4-12). While the term can be used for either real or animated girls, it is rarely used to refer to sexual content depicting real children.
